gemini_prediction.recommendation: Delete immediately and do not interact with it. Do not click any links or reply.

content.subject: Security alert
content.message:
[image: Google]
App password created to sign in to your account


spam.detection.viit@gmail.com
If you didn't generate this password for Mail, someone might be using your
account. Check and secure your account now.
Check activity
<https://accounts.google.com/AccountChooser?Email=spam.detecti

gemini_prediction.reason: This email is highly suspicious and likely a phishing attempt. The primary red flag is the truncated URL ('https://accounts.google.com/AccountChooser?Email=spam.detecti'). Legitimate security alerts from Google would never contain a broken or incomplete URL. Phishers often use legitimate-looking domains combined with truncation or slight misspellings to trick users into clicking malicious links. The urgent tone ('someone might be using your account. Check and secure your account now.') is also a common tactic in phishing emails to create panic and encourage hasty actions.
gemini_prediction.recommendation: Delete immediately. Do NOT click on any links in this email. If you are concerned about your Google account security, go directly to Google's official website (accounts.google.com) in your browser and check your activity there.
spam_words: someone might be using your account
Check and secure your account now

If you didn't remove this password, someone might be using your account.
Check and secure your account now.
Check activity
<https://accounts.google.com/AccountChooser?Email=spam.detection.viit@gmail.com&

gemini_prediction.reason: The email content, including the language, Google branding reference, and the explicit URL (`https://accounts.google.com/AccountChooser?...`), is consistent with a legitimate security notification from Google. The provided URL points to a genuine Google domain (`accounts.google.com`) and a known Google service, with no obvious signs of malformation or spoofing within the displayed text.
gemini_prediction.recommendation: While the email *appears* legitimate based on its content, always exercise extreme caution with security alerts. **Do not click links directly from emails** to manage security settings. Instead, if you are concerned, manually navigate to accounts.google.com in your web browser and check your security settings directly from the official website.

gemini_prediction.reason: The email consists solely of a single, generic word ('temporary') with no context, sender information (from the provided content), or subject line. This extreme brevity and lack of context are highly suspicious, often indicative of test emails for spam filters, attempts to verify email addresses, or vague phishing attempts designed to elicit a reply without revealing true malicious intent upfront. Legitimate communication rarely consists of just one out-of-context word.
gemini_prediction.recommendation: Be cautious. Do not reply or click on any potential links if it were part of a larger email. Consider blocking the sender if this is an unsolicited message. Delete immediately if you do not recognize the sender.

content.subject: Spam
content.message: Congratulations you have won 50,000 claim it

gemini_prediction.reason: The email uses classic spam tactics: an unsolicited 'winnings' notification, a large unspecified sum of money, and an urgent call to action ('claim it') without any context, sender details, or explanation of how the 'prize' was won. This is a common characteristic of prize or lottery scams.
gemini_prediction.recommendation: Delete immediately and do not reply or click any links. Mark as junk/spam if your email client allows.

content.subject: Security alert
content.message:
[image: Google]
App password used to sign in was removed


spam.detection.viit@gmail.com
If you didn't remove this password, someone might be using your account.
Check and secure your account now.
Check activity
<https://accounts.google.com/AccountChooser?Email=spam.detection.viit@gmail.com&continue=https://myaccount.google.com/alert/nt/1759980414556?rfn%3D269%26rfnc%3D1%26eid%3D-7453576354914350220%26et%3D0>
You can also see security activity at
https://myaccount.google.com/notifications
You received this email to let you know about important changes to your
Google Account and ser

gemini_prediction.reason: The email content, including the specific mention of the recipient's email address (spam.detection.viit@gmail.com) and the use of legitimate Google URLs (accounts.google.com and myaccount.google.com) for security activity and account management, strongly suggests it's a genuine security notification from Google regarding an 'App password' removal. The language and call to action are consistent with authentic security alerts.
gemini_prediction.recommendation: Be cautious. While the email appears legitimate based on its content and links, it's always best practice to navigate directly to your Google Account security settings (e.g., by typing myaccount.google.com into your browser) and check for alerts there, rather than clicking links directly from an email, especially for security-related notifications. The truncated sentence at the end is a minor anomaly, but not enough to classify it as definite spam given the strong indicators of legitimacy.

gemini_prediction.reason: The email content consists solely of a common greeting ('Hello'). Without any additional context, such as a sender, subject line, or further body text, there are no indicators of spam (e.g., suspicious links, urgent requests, financial offers, grammatical errors). It's an incomplete message, but not inherently spam based on the provided text.
gemini_prediction.recommendation: Be cautious. While the content itself is not spam, very short, context-less emails can sometimes be precursors to phishing attempts or tests by spammers. If the sender is unknown or unexpected, do not reply or click any links if they appear in a subsequent message without verifying the sender's legitimacy.
